Award.AwardTitle: ABI innovation: Computational method for exploring the mysteries of cell-penetrating peptides
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to develop a new computational method and a web server for prediction of the cell-penetrating ability of naturally-occurring and synthetic peptides and analysis of their interactions with cellular membranes. Cell-penetrating peptides (CPPs) were discovered two decades ago and since then were used for delivery of various macromolecules into cells and tissues. However, the molecular mechanisms of passage of peptides through cell membranes still remain a mystery. To shed light on the mechanisms of direct membrane crossing by CPPs, an innovative theoretical method will be developed. This method will quantify the energetics of the processes underlying peptide entry into cells, including binding of peptides to membranes, their folding into alpha-helical and beta-sheet structures, and crossing the lipid bilayer by diffusion or by inducing membrane deformations, such as thinning, curving, or pore formation. The project is expected to have a significant scientific impact by providing unique methodology and the first public web server for discovery and design of novel CPPs. This method will be also valuable for analysis of interactions with membranes of a much wider spectrum of biologically active peptides and proteins with potentially beneficial or harmful physiological effects. The development and application of such general tool will advance scientific knowledge in the field of membrane peptides and proteins. An easy-to-use web tool will benefit a broad community of students, teachers and researchers engaged in the fields of biophysics, molecular and cell biology, bio-nanotechnology, and drug design. The project includes participation of students from the University of Michigan in development of the computational resources, as well as teaching K-12 students from socio-economically disadvantaged groups using videos, images, and tangible molecular models of peptides and proteins in membranes.

The new method will combine a thermodynamic model of secondary structure formation by peptides and an anisotropic solvent model of the lipid bilayer that accounts for specific polarity profiles, curvature, elastic moduli, and transmembrane potential in different biological membranes. The proposed methodology will be extensively tested and implemented on a public web server that will allow the following: (1) to quantify membrane-peptide interactions, energy and binding modes, including deformations of the lipid bilayer by peptides (PPM 3.0); (2) to perform modeling of membrane-bound beta-sheets and alpha-helices, including generation and optimization of their all-atom three-dimensional structures (FMAP 2.0); and (3) to predict potential CPPs by calculating and evaluating their possible translocation mechanisms, pathways and energy barriers in the lipid bilayer (CPPpred). The CPPpred server will generate all-atom three-dimensional structures of peptides, estimate their membrane binding modes and energy barriers along the translocation pathway, and evaluate mechanisms of peptide translocation using their amino acid sequence and parameters of specific membranes as input. The high computational efficiency of the method will allow its application for large-scale computational screening of peptide databases to identify potential CPPs.

Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cell-penetrating peptides (CPPs) are known for their ability to enter living cells and deliver various macromolecules into cells and tissues. Despite significant advances in the discovery of new CPPs, our current understanding of mechanisms by which peptides enter into cells offers little predictive power. Based on experimental observations, a CPP can cross membrane barriers using a number of mechanisms ranging from spontaneous membrane translocation with or without membrane disruption to active internalization followed by an endosomal escape. The exact mechanism depends on peptide properties, membrane composition, and experimental conditions.   

To shed light on the mechanisms guiding direct translocation of peptides through the lipid bilayer, this project developed an innovative, physics-based CellPM (Cell Permeability Modeling) method for calculating optimal translocation pathways and permeability coefficients of CPPs. This method is based on the heterogeneous solubility-diffusion theory, the anisotropic solvent model for the lipid bilayer, and the universal solvation model that accounts for hydrophobic interactions, solute-solvent hydrogen bonding, electrostatic energy of dipoles and ions, and the preferential solvation of polar groups by water. It operates using all-atom 3D structures of peptides that can be either experimentally obtained or modeled by the server from the amino acid sequence. This method quantifies the energetics of the translocation process, including membrane binding, peptide folding into stable secondary structures, and crossing of the lipid bilayer by switching from surface to transmembrane orientation and transverse diffusion. The possibilities of peptide-induced membrane thinning and curvature changes are also considered. This newly designed CellPM method and a corresponding easy-to-use public web server are set to contribute to the progress in the fields of biophysics, bioengineering, medicinal chemistry, and pharmacology. The method can be used for de novo design of spontaneous membrane-translocating peptides that can be suitable for systematic delivery of otherwise impermeable small molecule drugs. The new web tool can also assist in the development of bioactive peptides with enhanced cytosolic delivery, which can serve as inhibitors of protein-protein interactions in cells with a potential therapeutic use.

This project yielded broader impacts by providing computer science students with the opportunity to learn web tool development, new web technologies, and programming languages and apply them to create novel solutions in the field of biophysics. The acquired professional skills and training helped launch their careers in Information Technology. The developed tool was used in the curriculum for a graduate-level medicinal chemistry course and web-based workshops. Further, the project supported biology education in a public school with a high percentage of underrepresented minority students.


Last Modified: 06/03/2019
Modified by: Andrei Lomize

Image
  • Spontaneous translocation of peptides across membranes. Membrane translocation pathways and transfer energy profiles of tansportan (left panel) and a shortened variant TP10 (right panel). CellPM predicts that TP10 has a better translocation activity than transportan, in agreement with experiments.
    A. Lomize and I. Pogozheva
    Copyrighted
    Andrei Lomize
    Translocation pathway of transportan and TP10 calculated by the CellPM web server.

Based on experimental observations, a CPP can cross membrane barriers using a number of mechanisms ranging from spontaneous membrane translocation with or without membrane disruption to active internalization followed by an endosomal escape. The acquired professional skills and training helped launch their careers in Information Technology.
